title: 115_hr5687
content: The Act is titled the "Securing Opioids and Unused Narcotics with Deliberate Disposal and Packaging Act of 2018" or the "SOUND Disposal and Packaging Act." It introduces safety-enhancing packaging and disposal features for certain drugs. The Secretary may issue an order requiring the holder of a covered application to implement technologies for packaging or disposal of drugs to mitigate abuse or misuse, after consulting with stakeholders. The Secretary may issue an order requiring technologies, controls, or measures to reduce the risk of abuse or misuse of a drug listed in a covered application, while ensuring patient access is not unduly burdened. The order may provide options for implementing these measures. The Secretary may issue orders to implement technologies, controls, or measures to reduce drug abuse or misuse, including referencing packaging or disposal standards. Orders can apply to a specific drug class after consultation with stakeholders. The holder of a covered application must submit proposed changes to comply with an order issued by the Secretary within 180 calendar days, or a longer period specified by the Secretary. Alternatively, a requested alternative date may be agreed upon if submitted within 60 calendar days of the order. The holder of a covered application must implement approved changes within 90 calendar days or a longer period approved by the Secretary. Alternative technologies and controls may be proposed and approved by the Secretary. The Secretary may approve alternative technologies, controls, or measures for packaging, storage, or disposal of drugs if supported by data showing they mitigate abuse or misuse. Disputes regarding submitted supplements can be resolved through specified procedures. In this section, the term 'covered application' refers to drug approval applications for opioids listed in schedule II or III. The term 'relevant stakeholders' may include various industry experts and professionals. The curr_chunk discusses prohibited acts related to drug approval under a covered application. It also mentions the required content of an Abbreviated New Drug Application. Various stakeholders are involved, including care providers, pharmacists, manufacturers, and government agencies. Section 505(j)(2)(A) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to include requirements for drugs containing opioids in schedule II or III. These drugs must have proposed technologies, controls, or measures for packaging and disposal that provide comparable protections to those required for the applicable listed drug. The amendment to Section 505(j)(4) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act adds a new ground for refusing to approve an Abbreviated New Drug Application related to drugs containing opioids in schedule II or III. The applicant must propose technologies, controls, or measures for packaging and disposal that offer similar protections to those required for the applicable listed drug. The labeling for drug products subject to an abbreviated new drug application must not be interpreted as changes to labeling not allowed under the Act or a change in the conditions of use prescribed in the labeling for the new drug. The labeling for drug products under an abbreviated new drug application must not be seen as changes prohibited by the Act or altering the prescribed conditions of use. Additionally, a report by the Comptroller General of the United States on available evidence must be submitted to Congress within 12 months of this Act's enactment. The curr_chunk discusses the effectiveness and availability of in-home controlled substance disposal products and packaging technologies, barriers to their use, and Federal oversight of these products. The curr_chunk discusses Federal oversight of controlled substance packaging technologies, including recommended technologies like unit dose packaging, and their effectiveness in preventing diversion of prescribed substances. The curr_chunk provides recommendations on whether in-home controlled substance disposal products and packaging technologies need Federal oversight and the potential role of the Federal Government in evaluating these products for efficacy. The House of Representatives passed the bill on June 19, 2018.
